questions.question: 1. The role of transverse tubules in the excitation of skeletal muscle contraction is:
options: To provide an inward path for the spread of muscle action potential.
To serve as the storage site for calcium ions.
To connect the sarcomeres end to end.
To allow entrance of Ca++ through Ca++ channels during the action potential.

questions.question: 2. The primary role of calcium in the activation of skeletal muscle is:
options: To cause depolarization of the muscle cell plasma membrane.
To remove the inhibition of the reaction between the actin filaments and the myosin filaments.
To activate the myosin molecules so that they can interact with actin filaments.
To help the release of Ca++ from sarcoplasmic reticulum.

questions.question: 3. Excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle:
options: Is mediated by the influx of Ca++ ions from the extra cellular fluid.
Ca++ ions either enter the cell from the extra cellular fluid or released from sarcoplasmic reticulum.
Is mediated via the sodium-calcium exchange mechanism.
Occurs when there is a change in the transmembrane potential.

questions.question: 4. The transverse tubule system of striated muscle:
options: Stores Ca++ for release during excitation contraction coupling.
Conducts action potential to the interior of the cell.
Contains cal-sequestrin to bind Ca++ ions.
Pumps Ca++ ions from the ECF into the S.R.

questions.question: 5. During excitation-contraction coupling, all of the following occurs except:
options: The action potential enters inside the muscle fibers via the T system.
Mg++ ions are released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum and act as activators.
Ca++ ions increase the ATPase activity.
Ca++ ions block the action of the relaxing proteins (troponin and tropomyosin).

questions.question: 6. Normal relaxation of skeletal muscle is the result of:
options: A decrease in ATP concentration within the sarcomere.
Breakdown of acetyl choline at Motor-end plate.
Active transport of Ca++ into the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
An increase in intracellular PH.
